text: RT @PeterAtlantic: The dilemma for Republican senators running swing states is they want the energy Trump creates, but not the divisiveness. What the past four years have shown is, you don’t get one without the other. https://t.co/nHLoNQGvhr

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @PeterAtlantic: Former GOP NH Sen Judd Gregg: "In almost all these states where Republicans are at risk, the election turns on, primarily, independent women voters. But they are very frustrated and antagonized by the president’s character. And so they’re in play.” https://t.co/nHLoNQGvhr

text:
RT @AdrienneLaF: “Well-meaning attempts to standardize the diagnostic process have created a false binary wherein you are a person with depression, or you are not.” 

In a pandemic, that medical model is breaking down. @jameshamblin’s latest: https://t.co/6FJ013pXLA

https://t.co/FkiIavLqAV

text: Muslims will begin Eid al-Fitr celebrations tonight to mark the end of Ramadan. Because of the coronavirus, the holy month has been a quieter, more isolated spiritual experience. @NesimaAberra and @arshraziuddin collected photos from past celebrations: https://t.co/0k1mYE1p2O

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/ America owes its existence, at least in part, to conspiracy thinking. Our special project “Shadowland” explores how conspiracy theories have captured the American mind and why they’ve become more powerful and dangerous than ever. https://t.co/itMvwMPyAm https://t.co/kuDWnWbNA3

name: TheAtlantic
text: 2/ In the colonies, a theory was born that King George III was plotting the enslavement of all Americans. Even with… https://t.co/oZYsY62rmU

text: 2/ In the colonies, a theory was born that King George III was plotting the enslavement of all Americans. Even with… https://t.co/oZYsY62rmU

text: 3/ Centuries later, conspiracism in America and around the world has destroyed great institutions, eradicated knowl… https://t.co/xEqJGKkHHG

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ In our June cover story, @AdrienneLaF dives into the pro-Trump world of QAnon, a conspiracy theory with messianic overtones and dark predictions. And it’s a harbinger of a world where facts and reality don’t matter. https://t.co/fWHU4sdtu7

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ In our June cover story, @AdrienneLaF dives into the pro-Trump world of QAnon, a conspiracy theory with messianic overtones and dark predictions. And it’s a harbinger of a world where facts and reality don’t matter. https://t.co/fWHU4sdtu7

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/ @JeffreyGoldberg examines how conspiracism became a threat to democracy. “Nonsense is nonsense, except when it kills. And conspiracy thinking, especially when advanced by the president of the United States, is an existential threat." https://t.co/OLDzghNivA

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/ @JeffreyGoldberg examines how conspiracism became a threat to democracy. “Nonsense is nonsense, except when it kills. And conspiracy thinking, especially when advanced by the president of the United States, is an existential threat." https://t.co/OLDzghNivA

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/ Birtherism—the belief that Barack Obama was born abroad—is more than a conspiracy theory, @AdamSerwer argues. It is “a way to express allegiance to a particular notion of American identity, one that became the central theme of the Trump campaign.” https://t.co/trkJseOAP2

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/ America owes its existence, at least in part, to conspiracy thinking. Our special project “Shadowland” explores how conspiracy theories have captured the American mind and why they’ve become more powerful and dangerous than ever. https://t.co/itMvwMPyAm https://t.co/kuDWnWbNA3

name: TheAtlantic
text: 7/ One American News has cultivated an audience hungry for conspiracies, @DevinGordonX writes. In recent years, the media outlet has become a favorite of the president’s and “an extension of the besieged, paranoid worldview that got him elected.” https://t.co/ffgFAW5jro

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/ Birtherism—the belief that Barack Obama was born abroad—is more than a conspiracy theory, @AdamSerwer argues. It is “a way to express allegiance to a particular notion of American identity, one that became the central theme of the Trump campaign.” https://t.co/trkJseOAP2

name: TheAtlantic
text: 8/ Conspiracy theories aren’t limited to politics. @MeganGarber examines how reality television rationalized paranoia. “Reality TV really does encourage viewers to question everything—in part because it nullifies the distinction between fiction and fact.” https://t.co/Oqk121f5Mc

name: TheAtlantic
text: 7/ One American News has cultivated an audience hungry for conspiracies, @DevinGordonX writes. In recent years, the media outlet has become a favorite of the president’s and “an extension of the besieged, paranoid worldview that got him elected.” https://t.co/ffgFAW5jro

name: TheAtlantic
text: 9/ @kait_tiffany uncovers how the devices keeping us connected during the coronavirus—cell phones and 5G—became suspected killers. “In the case of anti-wireless activism, the scope of the conspiracy widens to the point where it becomes a worldview.” https://t.co/guSk1A7sno

name: TheAtlantic
text: 10/ But what makes conspiracism so irresistible? @elcush, the “Shadowland” editorial director and a former conspiracy theorist, writes that at their best, conspiracies are “a reminder to both those with power and those without it that someone is watching” https://t.co/YLREnkOqC0

name: TheAtlantic
text: 8/ Conspiracy theories aren’t limited to politics. @MeganGarber examines how reality television rationalized paranoia. “Reality TV really does encourage viewers to question everything—in part because it nullifies the distinction between fiction and fact.” https://t.co/Oqk121f5Mc

name: TheAtlantic
text: 11/ And @robinsloan imagines what the world would look like if conspiracy theories reigned supreme, in his short story, “The Conspiracy Museum.” “Inside, you will find a literal hall of mirrors ... a kind of counter-history.” https://t.co/oYbPSqNuTW
